message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of amenorrhea, milk production, and bitemporal hemianopsia suggest a pituitary tumor or prolactinoma. MRI brain will reveal the presence of the tumor. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels, mammogram, and serum TSH and free T4 are not likely to reveal the diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a pituitary tumor, which can cause amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and bitemporal hemianopsia. The MRI of the brain is the test of choice to diagnose a pituitary tumor. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels and mammogram are not relevant to the diagnosis. Serum TSH and free T4 may be checked to rule out hypothyroidism as a cause of amenorrhea but will not reveal the pituitary tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and bitemporal hemianopsia suggest a pituitary adenoma, and an MRI brain is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis. Options B, C, and D are unlikely to reveal the underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a pituitary adenoma that may be causing hyperprolactinemia and compressing the optic chiasm. MRI brain is the best test to visualize the adenoma. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels and mammogram are not likely to reveal the diagnosis. Serum TSH and free T4 can help diagnose thyroid disorders, but they are not relevant to this patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's bitemporal hemianopsia indicates a pituitary tumor, likely a prolactinoma, which can cause amenorrhea and lactation. An MRI brain is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels are not likely to reveal the diagnosis, and a mammogram will not be helpful in this case. Serum TSH and free T4 are not relevant to the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and bitemporal hemianopsia suggests a pituitary tumor. MRI of the brain is the preferred diagnostic test for pituitary tumors. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels would not be useful in this case. Mammogram and serum TSH and free T4 levels are not relevant to the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has a pituitary adenoma, which can be confirmed with an MRI brain. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels and mammogram are unlikely to provide useful information in this case. Serum TSH and free T4 may be useful in ruling out thyroid dysfunction, but not for diagnosing a pituitary adenoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a pituitary adenoma, which can cause amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and bitemporal hemianopsia. MRI brain is the most appropriate test to confirm this diagnosis. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels and mammogram are not likely to be helpful in this case. Serum TSH and free T4 would be useful if there were suspicion for a thyroid disorder, but there is nothing in the patient’s presentation to suggest this.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bitemporal hemianopsia and galactorrhea suggest pituitary adenoma, which can be confirmed with an MRI of the brain. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels are not useful in diagnosing pituitary adenomas. Mammograms are used for breast cancer screening and serum TSH and free T4 are used for thyroid function testing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a pituitary tumor, specifically a prolactinoma, which can cause amenorrhea and galactorrhea as well as visual field defects. An MRI of the brain will reveal the tumor. Serum estrogen and progesterone levels, mammogram, and serum TSH and free T4 are not specific for a pituitary tumor.
